contentrichtext.text: {{ otheruses }} [[File:La hamada noire du Tademayt 1890.jpg|thumb|upright=1.3|The 'black' hamada at [[Tademayt]], [[Algeria]]]] A '''hamada''' ([[Arabic language|Arabic]], حمادة <!-- Please bring up any changes to the Arabic script on the talk page before changing it on this page-->''ḥammāda'') is a type of [[desert]] landscape consisting of high, largely barren, hard, rocky plateaus, with very little [[sand]] because this has been removed by [[aeolian processes|deflation]].<ref name=Springer>{{cite web | url=http://www.springerreference.com/docs/html/chapterdbid/43197.html | title=Hamada, Reg, Serir, Gibber, Saï | publisher=Springer Reference | date=2013 | accessdate=2013-05-23}}</ref> ==Formation== Hamadas are produced by the wind removing the fine products of weathering: an aeolian process known as [[aeolian processes|deflation]]. The finer-grained products are removed in suspension, whilst the sand is removed through [[saltation (geology)|saltation]] and [[Aeolian_landform#Mechanism|surface creep]], leaving behind a landscape of [[gravel]], [[boulder|boulders]] and bare rock.<ref>B.W. Sparks. ''Geomorphology'', 2nd ed., pp. 322-3. Longman Group Ltd. 1972. (ISBN 0-582-48147-3)</ref> ==Related landforms== Hamada is related to ''[[Desert pavement]]'' (known variously as reg, serir, gibber, or saï), which occurs as stony plains or depressions covered with gravels or boulders, rather than as highland plateaus.<ref name=Springer/> Hamadas exist in contrast to ''[[Erg (landform)|ergs]]'', which are large areas of shifting [[sand dune]]s.<ref>McKnight, Tom L. and Darrel Hess. ''Physical Geography: A Landscape Appreciation'', 8th ed., pp. 495-6. Upper Saddle River, NJ: Pearson Education, Inc. 2005. (ISBN 0-13-145139-1)</ref> ==References== {{reflist}} {{Topography-stub}} {{geomorph-stub}} [[Category:Deserts and xeric shrublands]] [[Category:Arabic words and phrases]]
